text: We at City Students' Union stand in solidarity with our friends at UCU as they continue to fight for Pay Equality, job insecurity, rising workloads and pay devaluation. Thank you everyone who came and support the student led protest! #ucustrike

text:
Join us this Wednesday 04 December 2019, 10am - 3pm in the Pavilion, University Building for a lovely little market hosted by City Students' Union, Chaplaincy and CitySport. 

We will have bake sales, photobooths, crafts, christmas music, carols and some lovely little winter warmers.
linkedText:
Join us this Wednesday 04 December 2019, 10am - 3pm in the Pavilion, University Building for a lovely little market hosted by City Students' Union, Chaplaincy and CitySport. 

We will have bake sales, photobooths, crafts, christmas music, carols and some lovely little winter warmers.

text: Vice President Education Saqlain believes students have always been at the forefront of fighting for what is right. Throughout history, we have managed to affect seismic changes in the fabric of society, sending ripples through a system that is unaccommodating for us as a collective. The student vote in the UK is of the utmost importance and has the power to tilt the scales of power. REGISTER TO VOTE TODAY! http://bit.ly/2D9I3t0

text: Brexit, the word still on everyone's minds. Before the original leave date of 31st October, City's Professor of Mathematics, Professor Mark Broom, analysed the UK's Brexit strategy through game theory scenarios. He referred to the UK government and the EU's negotiation as a Hawk-Dove game. Read the article here: https://www.city.ac.uk/news/2019/september/uk-eu-brexit-talks-hawk-dove-or-tragedy-of-the-house-of-commons
linkedText: Brexit, the word still on everyone's minds. Before the original leave date of 31st October, City's Professor of Mathematics, Professor Mark Broom, analysed the UK's Brexit strategy through game theory scenarios. He referred to the UK government and the EU's negotiation as a Hawk-Dove game. Read the article here: https://www.city.ac.uk/news/2019/september/uk-eu-brexit-talks-hawk-dove-or-tragedy-of-the-house-of-commons

text: What is your favourite thing about London? We are based in Clerkenwell (central London), which is one of the most significant design hubs in the world, but London provides a lot more than that. A variety of food, cultural experiences, endless shopping. Name it, we've got it. Okay, maybe we don't have everything (sorry, there isn't a beach). See what some of our students like about this capital city here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mIYNB2BrUkk&list=PL-fOTakP4gHb7QQ3h8HQ2njwjEi87SijR&index=3
linkedText: What is your favourite thing about London? text: A nice throwback to some of our successful entrepreneurs. These gentlemen created an engineering company which is now the world's leading provider of life saving gas sensing solutions. They do this by improving the quality of gas detection through innovative technology.

text: The world will never stop trying to get more women working in STEM careers. Not only does it mark change and the fact women can do what men can do, it also opens the door to new discoveries and inventions. At the beginning of 2019, City hosted a special panel discussion about Women in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics). It was held on Ada Lovelace's birthday, the world’s first computer programmer. Read about it here: https://www.city.ac.uk/news/2019/january/city-academics-talk-about-women-in-stem
linkedText: The world will never stop trying to get more women working in STEM careers. Not only does it mark change and the fact women can do what men can do, it also opens the door to new discoveries and inventions. text: One of our amazing students has designed a new gadget called DotC. It is a smartly designed dot display with multiple different functions, including a clock, the weather, built in Wi-Fi and the ability to speak. Read more about it and see the different colour options here: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/220465991/dotc-clock-calendar-and-weather-station-shown-with-dots/description

text: Our final #CityIcon that we're sharing in celebration of our 125th Anniversary is Professor Pam Parker, Deputy Director for the Department of Learning Enhancement and Development at City 🌟 Pam has had a 20-year career of providing expert teaching and improving standards in higher education. Under her guidance, the Master’s in Academic Practise has become one of the best in the country. Working in both the City Health Sciences and the The City Law School Pam has taught and developed students from undergraduate through to PhD level. 📽️http://ow.ly/mL7b50x3FBy

text: Last week, 16 student-led businesses competed at CityBar for cash prizes and the attention of business leaders at the annual #CitySpark Christmas Marketplace event. With students from all of our five schools competing, there was a diverse range of products on display, including cutting edge technology alongside traditional media. Well done to all involved and thanks to City Launch Lab/ City Ventures team for organising such a great event! 💥 Read more: http://ow.ly/nFwk50xpxNK

text: Professor Raoul Franklin is a physicist, who served as Vice-Chancellor of City from 1978 – 1998 and is our next #CityIcon 🌟 He was a true visionary and built some of the key foundations that City stands on today. The University transformed under his leadership to meet changing business and economic needs, against a backdrop of government cuts and declining student numbers. His work resulted in the university winning four Queen's Awards for Enterprise (for technology, in 1982 and 1985 and for export, in 1988 and 1991). He was made CBE for his service to the University in 1994. 📽️ http://ow.ly/zekC50x3CPT
linkedText: Professor Raoul Franklin is a physicist, who served as Vice-Chancellor of City from 1978 – 1998 and is our next #CityIcon 🌟 He was a true visionary and built some of the key foundations that City stands on today. The University transformed under his leadership to meet changing business and economic needs, against a backdrop of government cuts and declining student numbers. His work resulted in the university winning four Queen's Awards for Enterprise (for technology, in 1982 and 1985 and for export, in 1988 and 1991). He was made CBE for his service to the University in 1994. 📽️ http://ow.ly/zekC50x3CPT
